column12:
Cato was founded in 2015. Our founders and many of our employees have an extensive security background.
Our CEO and Co-Founder Shlomo Kramer is in the hall of fame of cyber security and has co-founded companies such as Check Point (first commercial firewall) and Imperva (first web application firewall), he also was the first investor in Palo Alto Networks.
Since 2015 Cato's vision has been to converge Network and Security in a cloud-native and cloud-delivered service.

column12:
Cato dynamically monitors the quality of each Internet circuit to make real-time decisions upon failover between circuits to maintain user experience and availability. The thresholds for detecting a “Brown-out” situation are entirely configurable by the customer's administrators.
Additionally, Cato offers an additional service to proactively monitor customers’ Internet circuits and raise ISP support tickets on the customer's behalf through resolution. Cato Intelligent last-mile Management (ILMM) is a global, last-mile monitoring and management service designed for today’s enterprise. 
Cato ILMM monitors the complete last mile from the site through the ISP to the Cato PoP for brownout and blackout detection. 
Instead of being limited to the router's capabilities, Cato uses its Cato Socket for last-mile monitoring. By default, Cato Sockets measure latency, loss, and jitter using four different methods — DNS, HTTP, ping, and traceroute — although custom services can also be defined. Test results are then compared against the link profile generated during the onboarding process. Cato uses its data warehouse capabilities to construct detailed profiles of last-mile performance for each monitored service. These profiles are continuously updated to reflect seasonal variations in traffic conditions. By comparing test results against the link profiles, Cato can detect brownouts, not just link outages. 
Once problems are identified, Cato proactively works with ISPs to resolve them to minimize or eliminate user impact. Detailed reports backed by extensive logs identify the source of networking problems, shortening the time for ISPs to resolve problems. 
While most last-mile monitoring services stop at the ISP’s premises, Cato’s ILMM monitors the link from the Cato Socket through the ISP and all the way to the Cato PoP around the clock, seven days a week, 365 days a year.
column30: Yes

column12:
Cato provides 24x7x365 support for all customers via 3 tiers of service teams in 3 primary global regions, spanning 6 global time zones.
These Cato service/support teams are centered in the following locations: US-West, US-East, UK, Netherlands, Israel, Singapore and the Philippines. 
A direct escalation path via on-duty manager is always available to customers for incident/support need prioritization - which includes 2 direct support management contacts (VP Global Product Support and VP Operations).
There are 3 Response Time categories for Cato support, each with their own SLAs:
• Tier 3 (Low) initial response w/in 1 business day, updates every 4 business days
• Tier 2 (Medium) initial response w/in 4 hours, updates every 1 business day
• Tier 1 (High) initial response w/in 2 hours, updates every 2 hours
Additional support options are available:
• Cato's Tech Self Service Portal (https://supportme.catonetworks.com/)
• Cato's KnowledgeBase (https://support.catonetworks.com/hc/en-us)
• Cato's health status page (https://status.catonetworks.com) 
• Premium support: DSE (Designated Support Engineer) and TAM (Technical Account Manager)
• Cato's global professional services team offers assistance in planning, deployment, migration, expansion and any project related to the solution.
Current support quality statistic:
• CSAT Rating: 97.8 out of 100
• Average first response time: 10 minutes
• Average resolution time: 18 minutes
• Average ticket volume: About 9000 tickets per month
• SLA breaches related to infrastructure outages in the past 12 months that required relief granted to customers: Zero
• SLA breaches related to Support SLA in the past 12 months that required relief granted to customers: Zero
• The average tenure of support staff: 1.3 years
Cato's service SLA is publically available on our website: https://www.catonetworks.com/msa/

column12:
The Cato service delivers prioritization end-to-end from the point of the Cato socket device to the destination Cato socket. Customers can define and manage prioritization and bandwidth from a centralized location with as much granularity as required. Configuring the organization's QoS policies is done through BW Management profiles. These profiles define priorities and limit upstream/downstream bandwidth to a fixed speed or a percentage of the total bandwidth.
 
Analyzing QoS in real time or viewing historical data: When configuring a Cato site within the Cato Management Application (CMA), the administrator also configures the upstream/downstream bandwidth capacity. In this way, the Cato Cloud is aware of each link's capacity and can further leverage it in the QoS engine.
 
As part of the QoS engine, Cato continuously monitors each link’s quality matrix (congestion, packet loss, jitter, latency) and dynamically sends traffic over the best available link as configured in the PBR. Furthermore, Cato uses Weighted Random Early Drop (WRED). Before discarding a packet (due to lack of capacity), Cato buffers a minimum threshold of 250 packets and an upper threshold of 500 packets. You can analyze discarded packets using the analytics view.
 
Network rules allow the administrator to define Policy-Based Routing to steer traffic over Cato or other available transport paths (such as MPLS) while also controlling ISP Circuit selection, Packet Loss Mitigation, and more. The network rules can be based on Src / Dst, AD User or User Group, Application or Application Group, Service, and manually defined logical grouping.
 
The PBR comprises the following main functions:
 
• Transport Selection: you can define through which transport (such as Cato or Alt. WAN) to transfer specific traffic. For example, if a site has Alt. WAN (MPLS) as well as an internet link, you can define a PBR where certain WAN traffic is directed over MPLS while the remaining traffic and internet is directed over the Cato Cloud
• NIC Selection: you can define through which NIC to transfer specific traffic. For example, if a site has multiple internet lines, you can define a PBR where one NIC is used for all business apps while another NIC is used for non-business apps.
• Egressing or NAT from the Cato Cloud: you can select via which PoP(s) or IP(s) specific traffic should be egressed from the Cato Cloud, as explained in the following examples:
• Egressing from a specific location (Route via): If you want to optimize specific internet traffic to egress from the Cato Cloud closer to the target location, or to egress specific locations for localization purposes.
  
For each BW Management profile, you assign a number defining its priority. When you assign these prioritized profiles to the Network Rules, you effectively implement traffic prioritization, including throttling traffic per defined limits in the BW Management profile when links are congested.
 
 
Cato provides a set of predefined priorities (which can be added, modified, or deleted) assigned to the predefined network rules as follows:
  
P10: Prioritizing Voice & Video traffic across WAN and Internet
P20: Prioritizing RDP traffic across WAN and Internet
P30: Prioritizing SMB traffic across WAN and Internet
P40: Prioritizing the rest of the WAN traffic
Default: Prioritizing the rest of the Internet traffic is used as default priority when a Networking Rule doesn’t have a QoS context (meaning no specific priority should be assigned).

column12:
Cato fully complies with either design, full/partial mesh.  Because we are user-aware (integrating with Active Directory), we can also offer partial mesh designs based on employees, business divisions and user-groups as opposed to the more traditional site-based topologies.

Mobile and remote users are also able to access the full/partial mesh of the Cato Cloud. Every POP also serves as a VPN concentrator so no matter where the user, their routing internally and externally will be optimized.

column12:
Cato natively supports cloud applications (SaaS) resources as well as cloud datacenters (IaaS) without additional configuration, complexity, or point solutions. Specific optimizations include Shared Internet Exchange Points.
Like content delivery networks (CDNs), the Cato PoPs collocate in data centers directly connected to the IXP of the leading IaaS providers, such as Amazon AWS, Microsoft Azure, and Google CloudPlatform. Traffic from Cato customer sites and devices is optimized and routed via the shortest and fastest path from the Cato Cloud to the customer’s cloud infrastructure provider. As a result, latency to the cloud is comparable to optimized access provided by cloud providers, such as AWS DirectConnect or Azure Express Route, without the additional charge of optimized access offerings.
column15: Over commodity internet or private circuit  (ExpressRoute or Direct Connect)
column18: Virtual SDWAN Appliance via Terraform playbook into customer public cloud environment.
column24: IPSec Tunnel from cloud hosted gateway or customer can add a virtual VeloCloud Edge on the VMs.
column27: Over the top or direct router * (customer expense) if requested
column30: Windstream's Cloud Connect solution offers multiple geo-located private direct and shared ingress/egress points.
column33:
Customer may deploy an SD-WAN Virtual Edge in their Cloud Service Provider environment in Microsoft Azure, Amazon Web Services, Google Cloud Platform or Megaport.
AT&T will provide engineering support by AT&T Design Engineering, AT&T Implementation support, AT&T Integrated Service Experience, and AT&T Global Operations & Services Center. EdgeConnect Virtual (EC-V) appliances must be part of an AT&T SD-WAN with Aruba solution.
AT&T personnel will have no access to the customer’s Cloud service provider virtual compute resources, account, or console access to the virtual edge VNF.
AT&T may require Customer to access their cloud account to troubleshoot any problems that were identified in the CSP. AT&T and Aruba may participate in a troubleshooting triage with the Customer and the CSP to resolve the issue.
Cloud edges must always be part of a larger SD-WAN OTT solution that is provisioned as part of a larger MSP account for which AT&T has Orchestrator access. The virtual edge name as it appears in the Orchestrator must reflect a naming convention that conveys it is a virtual edge (e.g., xxCedge.xxx).

column12:
We have several Cato socket sizes, which are also offered in HA pairs.  These sockets are part of the subscription fee.
From the Socket to the Global Network the CATO Networks Platform is highly available throughout. The Socket can be deployed in HA, with Dual WAN which automatically tunnels to the nearest CATO PoP which is comprised of multiple Global Tier 1 providers in Tier 3 / 4 Datacenters across the globe. The physical infrastructure of the PoP itself is built in redundancy nodes all running the CATO network & security software stack. The Socket holds extra intelligence to automatically failover to the next closet PoP if the one nearest to it sustains a failure. Furthermore, if the CATO Global Network sustains a catastrophic failure, the Socket will fail open to the internet to allow traffic out and will automatically establish a site to site tunnel with each and every other Socket on the WAN, creating a Full VPN mesh.

column1: How can you optimize traffic to each of the below SaaS platforms?
column6: All of the below can be setup to arrive to the platform via hitting the CATO Cloud Gateways first or via direct internet breakout from the edge site. We welcome a discussion on what makes the most sense for your organizational needs while also prioritizing the traffing to/from these applications.
column12: Within the middle-mile (Cato Cloud), Cato PoPs choose the best, SLA-backed carrier for every packet. Routing on SLA-backed carriers end-to-end eliminates the packet loss incurred during carrier peering. With the optimum network determined, Cato PoPs act as TCP proxies, dramatically improving end-to-end TCP throughput. As proxies, the PoPs make distant destination appear closer to TCP clients and servers, which allows them to set large TCP windows. As a result, clients and servers can pass far more data at once before waiting for acknowledgement. Azure environments (IaaS) can be connected to Cato Cloud and enjoy all the above mentioned benefits. Cato Cloud eliminates the need for express routes as packets will always take the optimal route to the destination and Cato pop's are strategically placed near big cloud egress points for good connectivity. SaaS application traffic can be sped up as well by keeping the traffic in Cato cloud and egressing the traffic as close to the destination as possible instead of doing a local break out of the SaaS traffic over the unpredictable internet.
column30: SDWan technology allows you to create unique priority profiles to ensure optimized delivery of business critical applications. Windstream welcomes the opportunity to discuss the details around these critical applications and how we can design a resilient and efficient network to best support them.

column3: Palo SD-WAN supports Application Aware Traffic Steering and Dynamic path Selection to monitor and steer customer specfic applications.
column6: Cato also improves public cloud application performance, such as Office 365, Cloud ERP, UCaaS, and Cloud Storage. Latency is reduced by optimally routing cloud application traffic across Cato’s global, private backbone to the Cato PoP closest to the cloud application provider’s datacenter. Cato’s built-in WAN optimization maximizes end-to-end throughput to improve application performance, especially around bandwidth-intensive operations, such as file transfers. All traffic and files exchanged with the cloud application are subject to full security inspection within the Cato SASE Cloud.

column12:
The Cato service delivers prioritization end to end from the point of the Cato socket device, through to the destination Cato socket. Customers can define and manage prioritization and bandwidth from a centralized location with as much granularity as required:

• Configuring organization's QoS policies through BW Management profiles. These profiles define priorities and limit upstream/downstream bandwidth to either a fixed speed or a percentage of the total bandwidth.

• Analyzing QoS in real-time or viewing historical data

When you configure a Cato site within Cato Management Console, the administrator can also configure the upstream/downstream bandwidth capacity. In this way, the Cato Cloud is aware of the capacity of each link, and can further leverage it in the QoS engine.

As part of the QoS engine, Cato continuously monitors each link’s quality matrix (congestion, packet loss, jitter, latency) and dynamically sends traffic over the best available link and as per configured in the PBR.

Furthermore, Cato uses Weighted Random Early Drop (WRED). Prior to discarding a packet (due to lack of capacity), Cato buffers a minimum threshold of 250 packets and an upper threshold of 500 packets. You can analyze discarded packets using Cato Management Console's Site Analytics section.

Networks Rules allow the administrator to define Policy Based Routing to steer traffic over Cato or other available Transport paths, whilst also controlling ISP Circuit selection, Packet Loss Mitigation, and more. The Network rules can based upon, Src / Dst, AD User or User Group, Application or Application Group, Service, and manually defined logical grouping.

The PBR comprises the following main functions:

• Transport Selection: you can define through which transport (such as Cato or Alt. WAN) to transfer specific traffic. For example, if a site has Alt. WAN (MPLS) as well as an internet link, you can define a PBR where certain WAN traffic is directed over MPLS while the remaining traffic and internet is directed over the Cato Cloud

• NIC Selection: you can define through which NIC to transfer specific traffic. For example, if a site has multiple internet lines, you can define a PBR where one NIC is used for all business apps, while another NIC is used for non-business apps.

• Egressing or NAT from the Cato Cloud: you can select via which PoP(s) or IP(s) should specific traffic be egressed from

the Cato Cloud, as explained in the following examples:

• Egressing from a specific location (Route via): If you want to optimize specific internet traffic to egress from the Cato Cloud closer to the target location, or to egress specific locations for localization purposes.

• NAT with a specific IP: If you need to egress with a specific IP to gain secure access to applicable SaaS applications (for example, egressing Salesforce traffic with a specific IP from Cato Cloud and populating that IP in Salesforce's whitelist increases overall security, and forces users to access Salesforce from the Cato Cloud, benefiting from the Cato Cloud Security Services Stack).

For each BW Management profile, you assign a number defining its priority. When you assign these prioritized profiles to the Network Rules, you effectively implement traffic prioritization which includes, when links are congested, throttling of traffic as per defined limits in the BW Management profile.

Cato provides a set of predefined priorities (as which can be added, modified, deleted) assigned to the predefined network rules as follows:

P10: Prioritizing Voice & Video traffic across WAN and Internet

P20: Prioritizing RDP traffic across WAN and Internet

P30: Prioritizing SMB traffic across WAN and Internet

P40: Prioritizing the rest of the WAN traffic

Default: Prioritizing the rest of the Internet traffic and used as default priority when a Networking Rule doesn’t have a QoS context (meaning no specific priority should be assigned to it)

column12:
Cato supports all of the table-stakes features of traditional SD-WAN: Forward Error Correction, Packet Duplication, Packet Ordering Correction and load-balancing over multiple WAN links.
It should be noted that for most SD-WAN vendors, this is where they stop. For Cato, this is only the beginning of our WAN capabilities.Cato’s unique Multi-Segment Optimization combines edge- and backbone-specific optimizations, allowing us to optimize routing and maximize throughput end-to-end to both physical and cloud destinations. For Cato, the key to performance is not so much what vendors do at the edge with SD-WAN parlor tricks, it is what we do between our POPs (the middle mile) to guarantee a truly better experience for our users.
Within the middle-mile, Cato PoPs choose the best, SLA-backed carrier for every packet. Routing on SLA-backed carriers end-to-end eliminates the packet loss incurred during carrier peering. With the optimum network determined, Cato PoPs act as TCP proxies, dramatically improving end-to-end TCP throughput. As proxies, the PoPs make distant destination appear close to TCP clients and servers, which allows them to set large TCP windows. As a result, clients and servers can pass far more data at once before waiting for acknowledgement.

column12:
The Cato service delivers prioritization end to end from the point of the Cato socket device, through to the destination Cato socket. Customers can define and manage prioritization and bandwidth from a centralized location with as much granularity as required. Configuring the organization's QoS policies is done through BW Management profiles. These profiles define priorities and limit upstream/downstream bandwidth to either a fixed speed or a percentage of the total bandwidth.
 
Analyzing QoS in real-time or viewing historical data: When configuring a Cato site within the Cato Management Application (CMA), the administrator also configure the upstream/downstream bandwidth capacity. In this way, the Cato Cloud is aware of the capacity of each link, and can further leverage it in the QoS engine.
 
As part of the QoS engine, Cato continuously monitors each link’s quality matrix (congestion, packet loss, jitter, latency) and dynamically sends traffic over the best available link and as per configured in the PBR. Furthermore, Cato uses Weighted Random Early Drop (WRED). Prior to discarding a packet (due to lack of capacity), Cato buffers a minimum threshold of 250 packets and an upper threshold of 500 packets. You can analyze discarded packets using the analytics view.
 
Networks Rules allow the administrator to define Policy Based Routing to steer traffic over Cato or other available transport paths (such as MPLS), whilst also controlling ISP Circuit selection, Packet Loss Mitigation, and more. The network rules can be based upon, Src / Dst, AD User or User Group, Application or Application Group, Service, and manually defined logical grouping.
 
The PBR comprises the following main functions:
 
• Transport Selection: you can define through which transport (such as Cato or Alt. WAN) to transfer specific traffic. For example, if a site has Alt. WAN (MPLS) as well as an internet link, you can define a PBR where certain WAN traffic is directed over MPLS while the remaining traffic and internet is directed over the Cato Cloud
• NIC Selection: you can define through which NIC to transfer specific traffic. For example, if a site has multiple internet lines, you can define a PBR where one NIC is used for all business apps, while another NIC is used for non-business apps.
• Egressing or NAT from the Cato Cloud: you can select via which PoP(s) or IP(s) should specific traffic be egressed from the Cato Cloud, as explained in the following examples:
• Egressing from a specific location (Route via): If you want to optimize specific internet traffic to egress from the Cato Cloud closer to the target location, or to egress specific locations for localization purposes.
  
For each BW Management profile, you assign a number defining its priority. When you assign these prioritized profiles to the Network Rules, you effectively implement traffic prioritization which includes, when links are congested, throttling of traffic as per defined limits in the BW Management profile.
 
 
Cato provides a set of predefined priorities (as which can be added, modified, deleted) assigned to the predefined network rules as follows:
  
P10: Prioritizing Voice & Video traffic across WAN and Internet
P20: Prioritizing RDP traffic across WAN and Internet
P30: Prioritizing SMB traffic across WAN and Internet
P40: Prioritizing the rest of the WAN traffic
Default: Prioritizing the rest of the Internet traffic and used as default priority when a Networking Rule doesn’t have a QoS context (meaning no specific priority should be assigned to it).

column12:
Managed remotely via the Cato Cloud-based Management Console (CC2), customers configure the following capabilities across single or hundreds of sites with minimal effort and via a single platform.

Dynamic path selection

Using the Cato Socket device (see attached data sheets), ISP circuit selection can be made automatically based on line quality (jitter, latency, packet loss) and also load balancing based on bandwidth availability over multiple ISP circuits. Additionally, the path selection be directed via business focused policies to ensure the traffic prefers specific circuits, based on matching criteria such as, Application type, User or User group, src / dst etc. This does not preclude non-preferred circuit from also acting as a backup should the first fail or become over contended.

Application optimisation

Cato takes the approach of network level optimisations rather than application level. With application level optimisations, comes significant administrative overhead per application, the risk of breaking an applications communications, and ongoing maintenance upon application changes and upgrades. Cato takes the approach of leveraging a Tier 1 based, SLA-backed backbone to form a low latency and predictable middle mile. Leveraging this backbine, Cato then implements TCP acceleration, providing optimisation at a network level, benefiting all applications, without the adminsitrative overhead.


Performance based routing

As well as having full control to set a preferred circuit for specific applications, users / user groups, sources and destinations, the Cato solution defines thresholds which if reached dictate the circuit path selected for traffic.

Dynamic cloud access

Cato connects IaaS locations to the Cato Network using either a vSocket or IPSec tunnel, resulting in the same visibility, access and control as physical locations. The Cloud environments can then be accessed from other Cato-Connected locations and also mobile users with the Cato Client installed.

Layer 4 firewalling

Layer 4 firewalling is supported on the Cato Socket device to provide control between locally LAN subnets, without the requirement for the traffic to first pass into the Cato Cloud for inspection. This maintains a low latency and line speed connectivity.

Layer 7 firewalling

Layer 7 firewall is support, for any traffic passed to the Cato Cloud. The inspection takes place at the ingress PoP, providing full application awareness firewalling, URL filtering, IPS and advanced anti-malware.

column1: Can you handle inbound traffic for hosted systems
column12:
WAN Optimization for IaaS & SaaS:Within the middle-mile (Cato Cloud), Cato PoPs choose the best, SLA-backed carrier for every packet. Routing on SLA-backed carriers end-to-end eliminates the packet loss incurred during carrier peering. With the optimum network determined, Cato PoPs act as TCP proxies, dramatically improving end-to-end TCP throughput. As proxies, the PoPs make distant destination appear closer to TCP clients and servers, which allows them to set large TCP windows. As a result, clients and servers can pass far more data at once before waiting for acknowledgement. QoS on Public Internet:
One of the most unique and compelling benefits of Cato's POP-based architecture is our ability to provide QoS over public Internet. Unlike any other vendor in our vertical, we control both ends of the last mile. Like an MPLS provider we control outbound traffic from the site to our POP. We also control inbound traffic from the POP to the site. This enables some very nice capabilities we can deliver over Public Internet: All SD-WAN vendors can prioritize data for outbound traffic. Cato is the only vendor who can provide inbound QoS typically reserved only to MPLS providers. For any application (internally hosted or SaaS), Cato can protect EF and mission-critical data on the inbound path. For example we can guard against VoIP or critical ERP traffic from experiencing loss-based congestion caused by a large FTP transfer, YouTube video or other bandwidth hungry applications. Without MPLS, no other SD-WAN vendor can make this same claim. Finally, we can rate limit inbound WWW and Best Effort traffic before it hits the bottleneck of the last mile. The net result is Cato delivers a quality of experience similar to MPLS over public Internet.

column12:
All that Cato requires is an ISP with either Static or DHCP Public IP where you can connect the WAN interface of the Cato Socket. Our customers create a site (define LAN, VLAN, IP address parameters) on Cato Management Console, and:

• For sites with Static Public IP from ISP - Using a Cato Pre-defined interface on the Cato Socket, our customers login to the SocketUI and configure the Public Static IP. Upon reboot, the Cato Socket calls home, upgrades and then allows you to attach Socket to the site template you created above. From there, all configurations for the site are managed from the Cato Management Console
• For sites with DHCP Public IP from ISP, even easier, just connect the WAN interface of the Cato Socket to the ISP, it will call home, upgrade and allow you attach it to the site you created above. Once again, from there, all configurations for the site are managed from the Cato Management Console.

column12:
Cato Cloud Access Security Broker (CASB) helps organizations cope with the perils of shadow IT. Beyond unsanctioned applications, CASB helps organizations control access to sanctioned applications as well, making sure only authorized users - using authorized credentials - are granted access.
Cato CASB has 4 major elements: Visibility, Assessment, Enforcement, and Protection. 
 
 
Visibility: Cato's CASB solution monitors all enterprise SaaS-bound traffic and provides a detailed shadow IT report which details all applications, both sanctioned and unsanctioned, being accessed and used.
 
 
Assessment: Cato's CASB utilizes a unique Application Credibility Evaluator (ACE) which automates data collection and enables a quick and accurate assessment of each application's profile, resulting in an aggregated risk score - providing insight into the application's purpose, publishers' credibility, degree of security or lack thereof, compliance, etc.
 
 
Enforcement: The "CASB Policy Rules" view (via the Cato Management Application) lists all defined rules with the applications they have been defined for, the matching criteria, the specified action to be taken in case the rule applies, the associated severity level and whether an alert or event should be generated. The list can be filtered to display a subset of rules with common criteria.
 
 
Protection: By unifying all the security services in a single software stack running in each of Cato's cloud PoPs, all SaaS traffic passing through the PoP is analyzed by all security services - providing continuous protection via rigorous, automated enforcement of customer-defined policy based on context.
 
 
Deploying CASB as part of Cato's SASE architecture simplifies the network and improves visibility and overall security by utilizing a fully converged security and networking software stack embedded into each PoP. Cato’s SASE Cloud also leverages a private global backbone to optimize SaaS application performance by implementing prioritization, QoS, TCP optimization, and packet loss mitigation techniques, and offering resilient connectivity across the globe. The converged software stack utilizes Cato unique Single Pass Architecture Engine (SPACE) which enables a unified view and decision process in contrast to the chaining of siloed stand-alone products. The same processing is applied to all traffic, including remotely connected users. Lastly, Cato's SASE Cloud offers single-pane-of-glass management, covering all security and networking services in a unified console.

column12:
Cato's EPP provides industry leading protection of your endpoints with a single console for management of threats from across your environment. The key benefits of Cato's EPP are:
• Cato's EPP solution is fully managed through the Cato Management Application. Admins can oversee protected endpoints from a unified console, consolidating user data, network information, and security policies.
• With EPP enabled, Cato protects both network traffic and your endpoints ensuring layered protection against attack. Cato utilizes BitDefender to provide industry leading protection against attacks.
• Using Cato's EPP you can consolidate alerts from all entities into a single pane of glass. For example, from the Events page, using preset filters, you can view an alert triggered by a malicious document on an endpoint. Then, from the same page view an Anti-Malware alert from a scan of WAN and Internet traffic for potentially malicious files. This enables you to analyze complex threats that span across your endpoints and network.
• As the same user entity is used across the Cato Management Application, this means that alerts also provide a single source of information. For example, adding a filter for a user displays information from EPP as well as Network or Access alerts. This avoids manually searching for the user in multiple vendor console.

column12:
WAN NGFW (east-west), Internet NGFW (Noth-south)+SWG (url-filter), IPS, Anti-malware & Next gen Anti-malware (ML/AI based), CASB, DLP, TLS inspection and MDR (Managed Detection and Response)
Cato’s Next Generation Anti-malware leverages machine learning algorithms from SentinelOne’s Nexus SDK, an industry leader, to provide NGAV and identify and block unknown malware. Unknown malware can come as either zero-day attacks or, more frequently, as polymorphic variants of known threats that are designed to evade signature-based inspection engines. As with our signature-based protections, our machine learning-based protections keeps all customer data private and confidential, as Cato does not share anything with cloud-based repositories.
column30: Yes, Windstream does have solutions which support that feature.

column12:
Cato's Next-Gen Anti-Malware (NGAM) processing includes:
• Deep Packet Inspection of traffic payload for clear and encrypted traffic (if enabled). File objects are extracted from the traffic stream, inspected, and blocked, where appropriate.
• True Filetype Detection is used to identify the actual type of a file going over the network regardless of its file extension or the content-type header (in case of HTTP/S transfer). Cato uses this capability to detect all potential high-risk file types, defeating evasion techniques that are used by either attackers or misconfigured webapplications. This engine is also used by Cato IPS providing more context during flow analysis and acts as a key factor in detection of malicious network behavior.
• Malware Detection and Prevention leverages multi-layered and tightly-integrated anti-malware engines. First, a signature and heuristics-based inspection engine, which is kept up-to-date at all times based on global threat intelligence databases, scans files in transit to ensure effective protection against known malware. Second, we’ve partnered with SentinelOne, an industry leader, to leverage machine learning and artificial intelligence to identify and block unknown malware. Unknown malware can come as either zero-day attacks or, more frequently, as polymorphic variants of known threats that are designed to evade signature-based inspection engines. With both signature and machine learning-based protections, customer data remains private and confidential, as Cato does not share anything with cloud-based repositories.

Processing happens at line speed, without impact to the end user experience. When a malicious file is detected, user access will be blocked, and the user will be redirected to a block page. Customers have the ability to configure Cato’s anti-malware service to either monitor or block. It is possible to apply exceptions for specific files for a set duration.

column12: Cato Networks’s optional Intrusion Prevention Services (IPS/IDS) offers several layers of protection, including Behavioral Signatures, Reputation Feeds, Protocol Validation, Malware Communication, Geolocation and Network Behavioral Analysis. One of the unique characteristics of Cato’s IPS is that it is provided as a service with zero involvement required from the customer. Cato Research Labs updates, tunes, and maintains IPS signatures, both those developed in house (based on big-data collection and analysis of Cato Networks’s traffic) and those originating from external security feeds. The customer will be alerted by email and on the Portal with detailed information on any security anomaly identified by Cato’s IPS Service.

Besides Inline CASB, Cato provides out-of-band (API-based) capabilities. 
SaaS Security API gives the ability to also monitor and react to traffic from remote users that connect directly to the cloud apps. This applies even when they are not using the SDP Client to send traffic over the Cato Cloud.
SaaS Security API inspects the content of a connection without using TLS Inspection. This is especially benificial to accounts that don't have TLS Inspection enabled. However, even for accounts that are using TLS Inspection, some cloud apps can't be inspected due to issues related to certificate pinning. SaaS Security API compliments Cato's inline CASB and DLP solutions to provide the best security coverage.

column12:
Cato's DLP is delivered as part of a SASE Cloud service and provides coverage for all traffic to all enterprise assets (premise datacenter, cloud, SaaS). This includes on-prem applications hosted in the enterprise’s physical data centers, which most DLP solutions do not have visibility into and therefore do not cover. Additionally, Cato's DLP follows Zero Trust principles in which we can define DLP rules for applications and activities for which no explicit rules have been defined. This means that we can enforce restrictive policies for unsanctioned applications (AKA shadow IT) and ensure sensitive content isn't uploaded to, or downloaded from, these applications before we have had a chance to better understand their purpose and potential risk.
Cato's Security Service Edge, SSE 360 , which is part of Cato's Secure Access Service Edge (SASE), converges DLP with additional application access and threat mitigation services. Cato SSE 360 uses a Single Pass Cloud Engine (SPACE) to employ these services concurrently and with a shared context, enabling each one visibility into information collected and processed by the others, to enable them to make better informed decisions. This also shortens the overall processing time and reduces latency, which is further optimized by the fact that TLS encryption and decryption needs to be done once for all services.

column12:
With a single, converged network and security stack Cato Networks sees all WAN and Internet traffic. The metadata of all traffic flows is stored in a massive data warehouse for further processing by machine learning algorithms and human researchers. The resulting insights allow Cato to deliver detailed security and networking insights, such as those necessary for threat hunting. Such insights are unavailable with traditional telco services.
With all Internet and WAN-bound traffic able to pass through the Cato Cloud in route to the destination, Cato provides optimization, predictability, security and visibility on all traffic.
Visibility is not limited to security violations, but covers Analytics on all traffic, providing realtime and historical visibility with the following granularity:
Per application
Per domain
Per user / host
Per URL category
Realtime and historical representation of lastmile Jitter, Latency and Packet loss are augmented by detailed data usage visibility.
 
Additionally, Cato offers a Last Mile Monitoring service (see attached) to monitor last-mile from the site through the ISP all the way to the Cato PoP for brownout and blackout detection. Rather than being limited to the capabilities of the router, Cato uses its Cato Socket for last-mile monitoring. By default, Cato Sockets measure latency, loss, jitter using four different methods — DNS, HTTP, ping, and traceroute — although custom services can also be defined. Test results are then compared against the link profile generated during the onboarding process. Cato uses its data warehouse capabilities to construct detailed profiles of last-mile performance for each monitored service. These profiles are continuously updated to reflect seasonal variations in traffic conditions. By comparing test results against the link profiles, Cato can detect brownouts not just link outages.
Once problems are identified, Cato proactively works with ISPs to resolve them to minimize or eliminate the impact on users. Detailed reports identify the source of networking problems backed by extensive logs, shortening the time for ISPs to resolve problems.

column1: Do all cloud firewall services apply to remote access clients
column12:
The Cloud gateway is part of the remote access solution. 
Cato is a SaaS platform that includes a ZTNA client for remote access and an SD-WAN appliance for SASE deployments.

At the basis of Cato’s SASE platform is a cloud-based secure network platform: Cato SASE Cloud. Cato took a cloud-first approach to its architecture and all functionality that could be delivered from the cloud, was placed in the cloud including global routing, network security, WAN optimization, and cloud acceleration. Cato deployed its network in 75+ fully redundant PoPs worldwide, where the full range of capabilities is available at all PoPs. Each PoP includes multiple symmetrical processing nodes, interconnected by multiple SLA-backed backbone providers. Next, Cato implemented a “thin client” approach to connect all edges to the Cato Cloud using encrypted tunnels. Edges includes Cato Socket SD-WAN appliances, any IPSec-enabled device (like edge firewalls), VPN-enabled cloud providers like AWS and Azure (agentless), and Cato VPN clients to tunnel a single device traffic into the Cato Cloud. This architecture is delivers HA by design. All edges automatically seek the nearest PoP and migrate to the next available PoP if the current PoP becomes unreachable. This requires no pre-planning or manual intervention. Traffic flows are processed inside each POP by the Cato SPACE engines using a single-pass scanning approach that processes the traffic in parallel and avoid the limitations and performance-related issues of a service-chain model. More info on our SPACE engine can be found in the attached document.
column18: Subscribed Cloud firewalls can be included as client gateways for remote client users.

column12:
The Cato Cloud is a converged platform to connect, secure and manage Coastal's network. Coastal Credit Union can gradually deploy Cato across branches, cloud resources, and users to replace or augment legacy network services and security point solutions.
At the core, Cato built a global private backbone of 93+ POPs (still growing) running our converged software stack. The PoPs are interconnected with redundant Tier-1 providers that commit to SLAs around long-haul latency, jitter, and packet loss. The PoP software selects the best route across providers, for maximum uptime and best end-to-end performance. This design offers an immediate improvement in network quality over the unpredictable Public internet, and a significant cost reduction over MPLS. 
Cato process every packet through multiple engines.
For network processing:
 -  Cato calculates the best routes globally for every packet, over the best preforming provider – this also creates high resiliency in case of a provider degradation or outage.
  - Cato accelerates WAN traffic by maximizing bandwidth for activities such as file downloads and voice calls.
  - And, it optimizes cloud access by routing application-specific traffic to the PoP closest to the cloud destination.
Cato then inspects packets for security.
 - All traffic, including encrypted traffic, can be inspected by multiple security engines.
 - These include a next generation firewall with application awareness, secure web gateway with URL filtering, and advanced threat prevention with next gen anti-malware and IPS.
 - Security policies apply to all resources including physical locations, cloud resources, and mobile users.
Customer connect all network edges to the cloud network using secure tunnels. Physical locations connect via Cato Socket SD-WAN devices. The Cato Socket manages multiple last mile connections in active/active mode. It moves traffic to the best path based on underlying link behaviour. The socket also applies quality of service prioritization based on application and user awareness. And, it protects critical apps like voice against packet loss. Cato provides a broad set of policies out of the box that optimize traffic for the most common requirements, with the ability to configure highly granular policies for specific needs.
Cato Sockets also support site-to-site MPLS and Internet connections for regional use cases and for bandwidth intensive applications with low security exposure like backup. Customers that don’t care for edge SD-WAN capabilities, can establish IPSec tunnels from existing routers or firewalls to the nearest PoP and get the network and security benefits or the backbone with a zero on-site footprint.
Combining Cato’s Edge SD-WAN capabilities for last mile optimization, with Cato’s backbone middle mile optimizations allows JGSHI to augment or replace MPLS and deliver optimal service to all locations globally or regionally.
Beyond physical locations, Cato connects cloud resources (e.g. AWS, Microsoft Azure) and mobile users to the network.
A mobile user can use the Cato Client or a browser, to securely connect to any WAN or cloud application from a laptop, tablets, and smartphones. The users dynamically connect to the nearest PoP as they move from place to place. Traffic is then optimized and secure over the backbone and to the destination.
Cloud datacenters are connected by establishing an IPSEC tunnel from the Cato Cloud or using a Cato virtual socket. This makes the cloud datacenter an integral part of the network and its traffic benefits from all network optimization and security controls.
For public cloud applications, no integration is required. Application-specific traffic from any edge is automatically detected. Traffic can be sent, based on a network rule, to the PoP closest to the cloud instance serving the business.
Finally, Cato offers a flexible management model. A Self-service console if available for Coastal to configure all networking and security policies for the entire system. Cato and its partners can deliver a fully managed service for customers who want it.
The Cato Cloud is a future proof network for the digital business. As needed, Cato can be gradually deployed across use cases while coexisting with your network and security infrastructure.

column1: Access to middle mile network for optimal egress
column12:
Cato Networks has integrations with the above mentioned providers at different levels:
1) MS Azure, AWS and GCP clouds can be interconnected to the Cato SASE private cloud through virtual sockets, IPsec tunnels or cross-connect (L2) allowing Coastal to seamlessly connect their cloud workloads to the network in a secure and optimised way. 
2) Access to SaaS applications like SAP HEC can be delivered through our SaaS Smart egress capability. Traffic can be forwarded, based on a network rule, over the Cato global backbone to the PoP closest to the cloud instance serving the business. This smart egress capability optimizes the user experience.
